newsitem.title: USA: Boeing posts higher profits on increased sales.
newsitem.headline: Boeing posts higher profits on increased sales.

text.p: The world's largest commercial aircraft maker, Boeing Co, said on Thursday its profits climbed 13 percent in the third quarter as it sold more planes and realised greater interest income.
Boeing said its net income for the three months ended September 30 climbed to $254 million, or 74 cents a share, from $225 million, or 66 cents a share.
The per-share results were a penny ahead of Wall Street estimates of 73 cents, according to First Call, which tracks analyst estimates.
Boeing said its revenues soared to $5.60 billion from $4.38 billion as it delivered a total of 54 airliners, up from 51 in the year-ago period.
Boeing said its sales increase was slightly offset by higher research and development costs associated with developing derivatives of its 737 airliner and a higher income tax rate.

For the first nine months net income soared to $841 million, or $2.44 a share, from $175 million, or 51 cents a share, a year ago, when the company took a $600 million charge related to an employee retirement programme.
Revenues for the first nine months rose to $16.17 billion from $14.98 billion, although the company delivered only 156 airplanes, down from 170 a year ago.

The company said the profit increase for the period was principally due to the settlement of various defence and space segment contract issues, resulting in an $81 million after-tax increase in net income.
Boeing said it continued to project total 1996 deliveries of 215 airplanes with sales projected to be in the $22 billion range, compared with $19.5 billion in 1995.
It also said that, based on current programmes and schedules, research and development expense for the full year will be about $1.2 billion, down from $1.3 billion last year.
The company said its effective income tax rate of 18.0 percent for the first nine months reflected recognition of a one-time tax benefit of $95 million related to prior years' investment tax credits.

The company had an 8.4 percent income tax rate for 1995, the result of the $600 million pretax charge for the retirement programme and the recognition of significant research and experimentation tax credits.
